title: Trompo
text:
A Trompo is a <a href="top">top</a> which is spun by winding a length of <a href="twine">string</a> around the body, and launching it so that lands spinning on its point. If the string is attached to a <a href="whip">stick</a> the rotation can be maintained by whipping the side of the body. The string may also be wound around the point while the trompo is spinning in order to control its position or even lift the spinning top to another surface.
Etymology.
These <a href="toy">toy</a>s are popular in <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a> where the name "trompo" emerged, but there are many different local names. In Spain, these toys may be called "trompo" or "peonza", "perinola", and "pirinola". In the Philippines, they are called "trumpo" or "turumpo", while in Portugal they are called "pião".
In India it is called Bugari (Kannada); children make these tops by nailing wood and spin them with twisted jute rope. In Japan, similar tops are known as "koma", with most cities having a particular design.
In Germany a "Peitschenkreisel" may also be called "Doppisch, Dildop, Pindopp, Dilledopp, Triesel or Tanzknopf" (roughly "dancing top")
In Morocco it is called "Trombia", and it is often made out of wood and painted in a reddish brown color.
In Dutch it is called "priktol" (see https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priktol). A "tol" is a top. An other type of top is the "zweeptol". A "zweep" is a whip. (see https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinderspelen and find "zweep" on that page)
History.
There is historical evidence suggesting the existence of trompos as early as 4000 BCE, and trompos have been found on the bank of the <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates river</a>, likely belonging to an ancient civilization. There is also evidence that members of the ancient <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Greek</a> and <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman</a> civilizations used trompos as well. 
Description of motion.
The <a href="Gyroscope">gyroscopic effect</a> allows the trompo to spin over its point until the <a href="Gravity">force of gravity</a> ends up at an angle with respect to the top's axis of rotation, causing a variation in the location of the <a href="center%20of%20gravity">center of gravity</a> as the trompo undergoes <a href="precession">precession</a> (where the axis of rotation of the trompo moves in a circular path). The fall of the top is directly proportional to the angle between the direction of gravity on the trompo and the top's axis of rotation. The fall is also directly proportional to the magnitude of the force of gravity and is inversely proportional to the trompo's <a href="angular%20velocity">angular velocity</a>.
As <a href="Drag%20%28physics%29">air resistance</a> and <a href="friction">friction</a> with the ground begin to slow the trompo's spin, its center of gravity begins to destabilize and the top's bottom point begins to trace a circular path with the ground. Soon the trompo becomes fully unbalanced and it falls to the ground, rolling until it comes to rest.
This general motion is largely shared among many trompo variants, but differences in several design <a href="Parameter">parameters</a> (such as the <a href="mass%20distribution">mass distribution</a>, friction between the bottom point and the ground, and the spinning method) can still lead to significant variation in the aforementioned variables.
Form.
The trompo's form has varied enormously throughout history. Though trompos have traditionally been <a href="Cone">cone-shaped</a>, there are also diverse variations in trompo form across regions. However, despite these regional differences in design, all trompos are constructed to be capable of employing the gyroscopic effect.
Trompos generally have an approximately pear-shaped body and are usually made of a hard wood such as <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a>, <a href="oak">oak</a> or <a href="beech">beech</a>, although new resins and strong plastic materials have also been used. <a href="Clay">Clay</a> trompos have also been found from <a href="ancient%20civilizations">ancient civilizations</a> near the Euphrates river. Whipping tops often have a more cylindrical shape to provide a bigger surface to be struck by the whip.
A trompo has a button-shaped on top, usually bigger than the tip on which it spins, and it is generally made of the same material as the rest of the body.
The base of a trompo is a stud or spike which may have a groove or <a href="Rolling-element%20bearing">roller-bearing</a> to facilitate lifting the spinning trompo with a whip or string without imposing much friction on the body.
The trompo surface may be painted or decorated, and some versions incorporate synthetic sound devices. The small size diameter and low <a href="mass">mass</a> of most trompos means that mechanical <a href="whistle">whistle</a>s would cause excessive <a href="drag%20%28physics%29">drag (physics)</a> and reduce their spinning time.
The Philippine "trumpo" differs in the tip, which is straight and pointed. It usually looks like a nail embedded in a wooden spheroid. 
Play.
Playing with a trompo consists of throwing the top and having it spin on the floor. Due to its shape, a trompo spins on its <a href="Coordinate%20axis">axis</a> and swirls around its <a href="conic">conic</a> tip which is usually made of iron or steel. A trompo uses a <a href="pullstring">string</a> wrapped around it to get the necessary spin needed. The player must roll the cord around the trompo from the metallic tip up. The user must then tie the string in a knot on the button-shaped tip before releasing it. When rolling the cord around the trompo, the cord must be tightly attached to it. The technique for throwing a trompo varies. One end of the cord must be rolled around the player's fingers and with the same hand the trompo must be held with the metallic tip facing upwards.
Championships are held in different Latin American countries, especially in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, and <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> where it is very popular among children of the middle and lower classes.
In Mexico most trompos sold are made of plastic, with a metal tip, and sometimes they are made of wood. There is a popular game called "picotazos," where the main goal is to destroy the opponents' trompo. Another game is where a circle is drawn on the ground and a coin is placed in the middle, and the goal here is to strike the coin.
In Puerto Rico, trompos are sometimes played similarly to certain marble games, with trompos being placed in a circle drawn on the ground. The goal of this variant is to knock the trompos out of the circle. Failure to spin or spinning in the circle causes your trompo to be placed in the circle, and another person has a turn to spin. Trompos in Puerto Rico and <a href="Chile">Chile</a> are frequently modified to have a sharper point.
<a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Miguel%20Agrelot">José Miguel Agrelot</a>, a <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rican</a> comedian, hosted a long-standing television program, "Encabulla y Vuelve y Tira", whose name described the action of throwing and spinning a trompo. One of his comedic characterizations, mischievous boy Torito Fuertes, was a one-time sponsor of a line of trompos.
The Filipino "trumpo" is basically played in the same manner, except that a knot is not tied into the tip before throwing it for the spin.
